moves.1. e4:
Another game from the Chelyabinsk Variation mini tournament. This is quite a long game and I made a number of mistakes.

I would appreciate any comments about the end game, in particular anything I could perhaps have done better
moves.6. Nf3 Bb4: Possibly a little too aggressive, though I am now ready to castle
moves.7. Bd3: protects the e4 pawn as the knight is now pinned
moves.7... d5: More pressure on the centre and the e pawn, the d pawn also has one eye on d4 which will cramp whites position a little
moves.8. exd5 Nxd5: Applies extra pressure to the knight and extra support for my dsb
moves.9. Bd2 Nxc3: Trying to double whites pawns on c which will restrict his queens options
moves.10. bxc3 Bc5:
This move takes us out of the gameknot database.

My idea here was that this looked like a good place for my bishop as when he castles his f pawn will be pinned
moves.12. Nxe5 O-O 13. Qf3: All of a sudden he has some pressure on my f pawn but with his queen there I also cannot move my lsb without losing another pawn
moves.13... Qc7: Guards my dsb and allows me to move my lsb, completing development and linking my rooks
moves.14. Bf4: Presumably this is to try to make me move my queen again which means I lose tempo
moves.15. Rae1: Did he move the right rook here? I think I would have been tempted to put my f rook there and then allow the other rook onto b or d
moves.15... f6: Pressuring the knight further. however this was perhaps unwise as it opens up a nice diagonal to my king for his lsb and his queen that is currently on a light square.
moves.16. Qh5: Further protecting the knight but also threatening mate with Qxh7
moves.16... Bf5: Loses material but seemed preferable to Ng6 or g6
moves.19. Qe6+: I completely overlooked this move which of course allows his dsb to escape
moves.19... Kh8 20. Bxe5: and in fact gain a pawn
moves.20... Rfe8: Still trying to pressure the dsb (and failing as we will see)
moves.21. Bxd6: However I again missed this move, things are looking bad now
moves.21... Qc6 22. Be7 Qxc3: At this point I decided to try to grab as many pawns as I could
moves.24. Bxc3 Rc6: Still trying to gain a pawn
moves.25. Re3 Rac8 26. Ba1 Rc6xc2: His bishop is pinning my g pawn which could prove nasty
moves.35... Rxa2: Though this seems reasonable compensation as I now have 2 passed linked pawns
moves.38... a5 39. h5 b2 40. Bxb2: Clearly game over by this point. I only carried on so that I could look at the game later to see if at this point I could have done any better. Any comments would be appreciated
moves.42. Rg7+ Kf6 43. Kh2 a4 44. Ra7 Kg6: The idea here was that if he took my pawn I could at least get his h pawn and possibly his f one too
moves.45. h7 Rb8 46. Kg3 a3 47. Kg4 a2 48. f5+: I'm trying to limit his kings movement a little which I hoped may give me a chance for a draw
giving me more options for my rook
moves.55... Kf8 56. Kg6 Rh4: This is an attempt to distract my opponent, in the hope that he will push his f pawn forward and trap my king
moves.57. g5 Rc4: Looking to push his king away with c6 possibly gaining another pawn
moves.58. f6: he is now threatening mate with Rh8 ...
